Speaking with the archimandrite,the man decided to stay in the convent for the winter. He continued in his silence and weeping, garnering the appreciation of the brothers, who were encouraged by him.
While in the conventthe man refused to sleep during the night while others were awake, and during service he would lie on the floor crying, leading the archimandrite question him.
The archimandrite approached the man about his actions. Attending vespers, he began to cry because of his humility and sinfulness before God.

Close to death,the blessed man went into the vestry to pray. After a while,the archimandrite entered to find the man praying on his mat, as if he was asleep. As the Archimandrite spoke,the man gave up his soul to God.

Abraham died after thirty-eight years standing on the column.

Abraham, Cyriac, Barhadbshabba, and Sergius abolished paganism, overthrew idolatry, uprooted altars, destroyed shrines, and cut down trees in ardent religious zeal in the high mountainous region of Asia.
Abraham, Cyriac, Barhadbshabba, and Sergius helped John of Ephesus build ninety-two churches and ten monasteries in four provinces with the help of the heavenly power.
After mighty labors of abstinence, Abraham received gifts of the Spirit that enabled him to cure the sick and to drive out demons.
After laboring for ten years in the monastery, Abraham stood on a column to pray and fast.
Abraham and Maro gained a great deal of fame.
Because Maro's ascetic practices were so extreme and sometimes dangerous, Abraham convinced him to return to the shelter of the monastery.
Abraham, Cyriac, Barhadbshabba, and Sergius were all buried together in the the sepulchre.

Abraham calmed the angry mob and sent them away by telling them that he would examine Sergius inside the church. Once inside, Abraham and Anonymi 3689 beat Sergius severely before shaving off his hair, which marked his ascetic profession, and putting him in irons in order to transport him to the monastery of 'Tryz.

Sergius received a blessing from Maro and then set out to visit the churh in Amida. Sergius walked into the church in Amida, carrying a cross, and planted his cross on the chancel steps before seizing the preacher, Bishop Abraham, by the neck and throwing him to the ground. Sergius mounted the steps and addressed the crowd: Cursed are the renegades; cursed are the persecutors; cursed is the synod of Chaledon, and whosoever assents to it. Cursed is every soul that receives the oblation from you and assents to your opinion unless he repents. The crowd, a mixture of believers and synod supporters, responded with praise and anger.

Addai exercised his pastoral office by exhorting all to love the poor and repent from sin.

Five years after the Council of Chalcedon, when the monastery at Fardaisa was brought to indigence, the brothers approached Addai in his exile. To recover financially, they began planting vineyards throughout the mountains east of Anzetene. Merchants from Cappadocia, who would go as far Syria to buy wine. Selling wine allowed Addai to begin feeding the poor again.

Sometime after 451Addai was deposed by those attempting to enforce the heresy of the Council of Chalcedon. He exhorted the brothers to remember the poor, and retreated to his exile in the mountains east of Anzetene.

Though Addai remained reclusive, John and one of the brothers discovered where he would be. As the men approached, Addai fled. John returned to the monastery to rest. They met Addai the next day. Perceiving that Addai wanted his privacy, John stopped pestering him, but simply asked for a blessing and a prayer.
Addai lived as a recluse in the mountains for twenty-five years before dying.

Maro and Anonymi 3665 settled near Susan and Anonymi 3662. Many others followed and settled near the holy sisters. Anonymi 3662 and Susan did not wish to cause scandal by living in such close proximity to men, so they endeavored to leave their tower and go further into the desert.
After ten days, people of the village were moved by the sisters' weeping and distress and discovered that Susan had been living in the hermit's cave.

Anonymi 3695 went to fetch Anonymi 3662, who immediately came to the cave to retrieve Susan. Susan did not respond to their entreaties, since demons had visited her the day before disguised as the sisters in an attempt to dislodge her from the hermitage.

Maro and and his ten disciples had been Susan's neighbors in a monastery in Palestine before they were driven out of their monastery by the Chalcedonian persecution. They made their way to Susan and Anonymi 3662.

Maro and Anonymi 3665 felt ashamed once they learned of Susan's plan to remove herself and Anonymi 3662 to the desert and offered to build them an enclosed monastery with a tower within the village, so that they could be isolated but remain close to the other holy men and women who travelled to be near her. Susan reluctantly agreed.

Even though Anonymi 3662 managed to convince Susan that they were not demons, she refused to return to the monastery with them as she wished to live as a hermit. They agreed to bring her a jug of water and seven bread cakes a week for her sustenance on the condition that she will not leave without giving them prior notice. This went on for three years, during which time the fame of the Susan and her sisters grew.

Severus responded to John by refusing to accept the synod of Chalcedon as a repudiation of Nestorius and Eutyches, because the Chalcedonian creed and the Tome of Leo support Nestorianism; Severus does not believe that anathematizing Eutyches makes the Council of Chalcedon legitimate, because the followers of Arius were still heretics even though they repudiated the teachings of Sabellius.

Severus argued that by ordaining priests in a diocese that was not his own, Epiphanius was not violating the sacred canons, which only outlaws such behavior in the cases of bishops forcing themselves on other dioceses, citing the examples of Eusebius of Samosata during the controversy of Arius, Theodoret, Basil, and Gregory the Theologian.

To defend his belief in the ordination of priests by those outside of a particular diocese, Severus appeals to the examples of Basil during the controversy surrounding Arius, and Gregory the Theologian.

To convince Misael to remain in his position, Severus cited several scripture passages, as well as an historical anecdote of Anonymous 3057 and Anonymous 3058 who gave up their solitude in order to combat the heresy of Arius.

Habib brought justice to those being exploited by the rich.
Habib was so holy, that many would confess their sins to him without any prompting on his part. Habib performed many miracles and mighty works against his enemies.
After Bar Nbyl lived 90 years, he died, leaving the monastery in Fytr to Habib.
Habib sent his disciple Z'ura to pray over the demon-possessed man, who then died, his injustices being undone.

Confronting a man possessed by Satan,Habib returned to the monastery in order to pray. God answered Habib's prayer by striking the demon-possessed man with sickness.

A group of people from Persia approached Habib with two sick women, one demon-possessed, and one who was barren. Both were healed by the holy man, the barren woman concieving a son and bringing him to the monastery for baptism.

Hala kept silence except when he prayed the psalms and the liturgy and read scripture without interruption and taught his disciples throughout the night.
When strangers came to the monastery Hala would wash and annoint them.
Hala cleaned latrines, picked lentils from the garden, and cooked from food waste and wine for the poor by the gates.
The persecution came and the convents had all their poroperty taken from them, so Hala could no longer assist the poor.

Mar Samuel gained distinction in the conflict of persecution. Mar Samuel went into exile in the district of Claudias where he took up residence in the Convent of the Huts. He related the story of the establishment of the Convent of John Urtaya to John of Ephesus. This occurred 536/7 A. Gr. 848
Another old man, named Paul of Arzen, related the history of the Convent of John Urtaya to John of Ephesus.

The old man continuously asked the archimandrite of the Amida convent for a dismissal. Curious, John asks the man about his eating, sleeping, and prayer habits. He eats and prays the way he does out of recognition of human sinfulness.
Theodora built a hospital on Chios.
After his ordination Kashish traveled around Chios with John of Ephesus converting pagans to Christianity.
John continued to ask the old man for his teaching. In frustruation, the old man left Amida.
After hearing about the old man's practices, John repented of his sins.

John describes the lengthy process by which men enter the monastery of Anonymous 3762. After one month of testing they may become penitents, after three months they many be partially tonsured and wear a limited monastic habit. Only after three years they may become monks, fully tonsured and wearing the complete habit.

John prophesied that Christians would not be able to find ordaining bishops throughout the empire.After 529, John observed that potential priests could go to Alexandria,Constantinople without gaining ordination.
Sworn to secrecy by Zacharias, John of Ephesus did not reveal his ascetic practices to others until after the saint had died.
While traveling in Asia Jacob Baradaeus, Eugene, and Conon ordained Peter as bishop of Tralles.

John of Ephesus was involved in bringing about the conversion from paganism to Christianity of eighty thousand people in the provinces of Asia, Caria, Phrygia, and Lydia. This involved the founding of ninety-eight churches and twelve monasteries and the conversion of twelve synagogues to churches.
the monk who stole narrated his story, in great sorrow and humility, to John of Ephesus. And John comforted him, and advised the monk to go with him to the blessed man to ask for his repentance.
Abraham comes to Constantinople to petition John of Ephesus to become a monk. He experiences a period of probation before being accepted.
Abbi warns John of Ephesus about purity and chastity.
Kashish travelled to Constantinople with John of Ephesus, before returning to Chios, where he spent the final years of his life. He was buried in the monastery of Mar Mama.
While traveling in Asia Jacob Baradaeus, Eugene, and Conon ordained John as bishop of Ephesus.
Leontius grew up with John of Ephesus from childhood.
John of Ephesus visited Peter and Photius at the Monastery of the Fathers in the Enaton.
After many years of wandering, Leontius and Qashish joined the company of John of Ephesus at the Monastery of Yoḥannan Urṭaya and lived there for about twenty years until his death.

While John was ordaining priests in the Church at Tralles, John of Ephesus administered the eucharist during the ordination service. John also accompanied John to an ordination service in Mar John in Ephesus.
While traveling in Asia Jacob Baradaeus, Eugene, and Conon ordained John as bishop of Pergamum.
John of Ephesus, who was a monk in the Convent of John Urtaya, observed Thomas's ascetic practices and had many enlightening conversations with him.
Abraham, Cyriac, Barhadbshabba, and Sergius helped John of Ephesus build ninety-two churches and ten monasteries in four provinces with the help of the heavenly power.
John visited Theophilus and Maria in Egypt outside of Thella and received a blessing from them.

John of Ephesus attempted to provide financial assistance to the poor holy man Priscus by sending a certain gentlemen to give a tremissis (gold coin). Priscus refused and ran away but finally relented and took one follis.
John of Ephesus reports that Bassian and Romanus both died in the household of a certain great and believing man.
John of Ephesus attempted to provide assistance to the poor holy man Priscus by sending a certain gentlemen to give him a tunic and a cloak.

Anonymous 3720 returned to Priscus and they discussed his mode of life: his poverty and his apparent madness. Priscus explained that he did these things to be left alone in order to pursue God. Anonymous 3720 promised only to reveal his secret to John of Ephesus.
Sosiana predicted her death to John of Ephesus, and she died just as she said.
Sosiana acted as patron of John of Ephesus.

After the death of John, Sosiana gave expensive clothing and textiles as well as silver dishes and chalices to John of Ephesus for the adornment of church altars. She gave the rest of her possessions to the poor.

John of Ephesus found Thomas and Zota years later in the desert of Mendis by Mar Menas. Thomas's body was frail and sunburnt. He had dedicated his life to fasting, praying, so that by depriving the body he would purify the soul.

John continued to ordain believers, travelling to Lydia in Asia, Tarsus in Cilicia, and all of Syria before returning to Anthemiu in Constantinople.

While John was ordaining priests in the Church at Tralles, John of Ephesus administered the eucharist during the ordination service. John also accompanied John to an ordination service in Mar John in Ephesus.
After a time,John feigned illness again as a pretense to travel around the empire to ordain more priests. He travelled to Cyprus,Caesarea,Rhodes,Tralles,Chios,Alexandria,and Palestine.

Ephraim appealed to the king and queen, revealing that John was causing division by ordaining priests around the empire.Theodora, convinced that John had been laying sick in the palace, dismissed the charges.

John confronted Theodora about the corrupt bishops and the persecution of Christians. Theodora, angry, sought to punish the jealous bishops, but relented after John interceded on their behalf. She commanded John to cease his ordinations, something he was glad to do due to a growing illness.
John exercised judgment when deciding who he would ordain. The jealous bishops, meanwhile, plotted to reveal John's actions to the queen.
Jelous of the zealous activity of John, bishops and priests began to petition Theodosius to censure. The archbishop refused.
After the Council of Chalcedon, John was expelled from Gaza, and traveled into Alexandria, finally settling in the Ennaton.
Convicted,John resolved to perform ordinations, journeying into the city under the pretext of illnesses and seeing physicians. His cause was made known to the queen.
Theodora allowed John to stay in a great mansion. Here John set up altars to encourage exiled Christians.
Theodosius appointed John as bishop of Hephaestu.

Kawad, King of Persia attacked the City of Amida, slaughtered many people, took captives, and razed the Convent of John Urtaya in the year 502/3 A. Gr. 814
Because King Kawad's invasion destroyed the Convent of John Urtaya, Paul took up residence in Monastery in Orientals in Edessa.
The story of Kawad's invasion was related to John of Ephesus years later when he was a white haired man, living in the monastery at Beth Gubrin.
The Convent of John Urtaya was rebuilt after King Kawad's invasion, but on a smaller scale--both in the number of buildings erected and in the number of monks admitted.
King Kawad's invasion was devastating and drove many away from the Convent of John Urtaya. The white-haired man fled from Amida.
Kavad besieged the city of Amida from 5 November A. D. 502 to 10 February 503 for 97 days beginning on 5 Teshri II A. Gr. 814
Kawad ordered all of the Christian bishops and archimandrites to be arrested and put in a prison in Nisbis for seven years.

In 542 a great plague hit the empire and everyone was in perturbation and doubt and confusion. Mare, in affliction and sorrow, occupied himself to fervant prayer.
After spending five years with Paul,Mare exceeded his teacher in prayer, asceticism, and moderation. Many criticized Mare for the severity of his practices.

While staying with Paul,Mare was tired of being pestered by his family, so he left Syria and journeyed to Egypt and Thebais, where he went to and fro in the desert with the saints, observing the prayer practices of monks and solitaries.
After much prayer,Mare was led by God to Paul the Anchorite who received him as his student.

Followers of the Council of Chalcedon expelled Christians from Alexandria and Mare from his desert cell. On account of the persecution,Mare resolved to travel to Constantinople to err his grievacnes with the king and queen.
Mare confronted Justinian and Theodora concerning the persecution. Because of his words and dress, they esteemed him a holy man, and gave him a hundred weight of gold, which he promptly threw away.

When Marefinished constructing the martyr's chapel and he knew his death was close, he knelt in his coffin to pray for three days and gave up his spirit. The king and queen sent chamberlains, senators, bishops, clergyman, and monks to bury Mare.

Observing the holiness of Mare, Satan encouraged robbers to abuse him, under the impression that the queen's chamberlains were bringing him gold. Mare overtook his assailants by stealing their weapons and attacking them.
Feeling guilty about the hundredweight gold,the queen sent her chamberlains several times to Mare to seek his forgiveness.

Sergius mounted the steps and addressed the crowd: Cursed are the renegades; cursed are the persecutors; cursed is the synod of Chaledon, and whosoever assents to it. The community was expelled from the convent at Thella d Thuthe, so they returned to the monastery of the Poplars.

At beginning of the reign of Justinian,the community was allowed to return to their destroyed monastery. And they began to restore their convents.

Between A.D. 521 and 526 the community was forced to leave their monastery by the defenders of the corrupt synod of Chalcedon. The community was so large, that the monastery of Mar Mama in the village of Hzyn in Ṭyšf could not hold them.

For five yearsthe community attracted many into their company, some coming as far as Ingilene. All were impressed by the religious devotion of the community; all who joined them turned from sin, committing their lives to prayer, worship, singing, and monastic devotion.
When the community was at Mar Mama, a miracle occurred, where those affected by famine were fed by unending bread at the monastery after the fathers had prayed.

After five years in Mar Mara, the community returned to Amida, but because of persecution, relocated to the border territory of the East, near the hot springs of Abarne, settling at the convent of the Poplars.
The community was too large for the convent of the Poplars, so they constructed several buildings and homes.

John of Claudiopolis, when he received Severus in the house of Patrick, urged Severus to receive the synod of Chalcedon, not as a positive definition of faith, but as a rejection of Nestorius and Eutyches.

Severus responded to John by refusing to accept the synod of Chalcedon as a repudiation of Nestorius and Eutyches, because the Chalcedonian creed and the Tome of Leo support Nestorianism; Severus does not believe that anathematizing Eutyches makes the Council of Chalcedon legitimate, because the followers of Arius were still heretics even though they repudiated the teachings of Sabellius.

Pawlā refused to accept the Council of Chalcedon and on 27 July 27 A. D. 522 27 Tammuz A. Gr. 833 Emperor Justin deposed him and exiled him to Euchata .

Following Pawlā's acceptance of the Council of Chalcedon and a letter of support from Justinian , the Emperor Justin restored Pawlā to his episcopal see and he entered Edessa on 8 March 526 8 Ādar A. Gr. 837 .

After 27 June 525 27 Ḥazirān A. Gr. 836 , Pawlā repented of his opposition to the Council of Chalcedon , petitioned Justinian for the return of his episcopal see, and wrote a libellus affirming the council to Euphrasius the Patriarch .
In 520/1 A. Gr. 832 , the Emperor Justin returned Bishop Pawlā to his episcopal see in Edessa hoping that he would accept the Council of Chalcedon .
On 4 November A. D. 519 4 Teshri II A. Gr. 831 Patricius arrived in Edessa at the command of the Emperor Justin in order to urge Bishop Pawlā to receive the Council of Chalcedon or else be deposed.

After 4 November A. D. 519 4 Teshri II A. Gr. 831 , Bishop Pawlā refused to accept the Council of Chalcedon . When Patricius threatened to remove him from Edessa he fled to the House of Baptism . Fearing the command of Emperor Justin , Patricius removed Bishop Pawlā to Seleucia .
After 10 April A. D. 510 the Sabbath of the Resurrection A. Gr. 821 Pawlā became Bishop of Edessa .
On 30 October A. D. 526 30 Teshri I A. Gr. 838 Pawlā died.

Shortly after Sergius established the monastery of Qlwfyte, his adversaries came to pull it down. Sergius told his enemies that he would rebuild it each time it was destroyed, so they finally left him alone. Sergius rebuilt the monastery of Qlwfyte and invited Simeon to stay with him. Sergius died after Simeon's arrival.

Abraham calmed the angry mob and sent them away by telling them that he would examine Sergius inside the church. Once inside, Abraham and Anonymi 3689 beat Sergius severely before shaving off his hair, which marked his ascetic profession, and putting him in irons in order to transport him to the monastery of 'Tryz.

Sergius, who was the disciple of Simeon was also a monk and a recluse, who lived an aescetic life in an enclosure. In order to avoid idleness, Simeon and Sergius taught young boys and infants from their enclosure through a window.

Sergius received a blessing from Maro and then set out to visit the churh in Amida. Sergius walked into the church in Amida, carrying a cross, and planted his cross on the chancel steps before seizing the preacher, Bishop Abraham, by the neck and throwing him to the ground. Sergius mounted the steps and addressed the crowd: Cursed are the renegades; cursed are the persecutors; cursed is the synod of Chaledon, and whosoever assents to it. Cursed is every soul that receives the oblation from you and assents to your opinion unless he repents. The crowd, a mixture of believers and synod supporters, responded with praise and anger.
Sergius was greatly distressed by the treatment of believers by the persecutors and wept unceasingly in the presence of Maro, who had given him refuge.
After twenty years, Sergius received permission from Simeon to leave the monastery and shut himself up in a certain place close to the village.
Before Sergius shut himself away, he contended with Jews in the village by upbraiding them and burning down their synagogue with the help of twenty disciples.

John of Ephesus visited Sergius in his later years and received a blessing from him as he wept over what he stated was his unworthiness to serve Christ. Sergius continued to receive visitors in his old age, despite his illness.
Sergius and Anonymi 3698 put out the fire and built a martyr's chapel on the site of the synagogue. Anonymi 3686 burned down the huts in response and Sergius rebuilt them.

The supporters of the synod of Chalcedon used troops to expell people from their homes, and to arrest, imprison, plunder, torture, and kill those who did not support the synod. The persecutors then turned their attention to Sergius, first using honeyed words and then threats when he refused to leave his enclosure. Sergius anathemized the persecutors as they pulled him out of his enclosure and expelled him from the community.
Sergius set out to visit Maro the stylite, whom the synod supporters left alone until a certain bishop visited him and tried unsuccessfully to convert him to the Chalcedonian heresy.
Over the next forty years Sergius grew ill and frail in his enclosure.
Sergius and Anonymi 3698 tore down the synagogue that Anonymi 3686 rebuilt two more times before Sergius secluded himself in an enclosure.
Members of the church of Amida defended the Jews and prefered accusation against Sergius and Anonymi 3698.

Sergius was confined on the third floor in the middle of the monastery of 'Tryz and tortured. After some time, Sergius managed to escape by slipping out of his irons and jumping from the third-floor window. Sergius returned to Simeon and received permission to build a monastery in the settlement of Qlwfyte.
Severus of Antioch and Sergius had a friendship.
Mara, metropolitan of Amid had ecclesiastical authority over Stephen, Thomas and Sergius.

Severus asserts that an oblation delivery is only necessary for those without bishops, making it unnecessary for Misael. Severus appeals to the scriptural story of Elijah and the ravens, asserting that even impious priests can be vessels to deliver the Eucharist.
Severus encourages Georgia to glory in her unmarried state, because time will make her more mature, wise, and intelligent, allowing her to be a greater help, model, and encouragement to her husband.
Early in the sixth century, Severus wrote a letter to Misael the Deacon concerning the efficacy of the eucharist from impious priests.
Between 519 and 538, Severus sent a letter to Georgia, daughter of Anastasia expressing the merits of coming to marriage as an adult.

Severus appeals to Gregory of Nazianzus to prove the efficacy of the Eucharist regardless of its administrator. Just as Baptism is valid regardless of the priest, and the seal of the king is valid regardless if it's set it in gold or wax, so the Eucharist is efficacious regardless of the priest.
Severus sent a letter to the monks of Mor Bassus explaining why he takes a more relaxed attitude to commemorating the names of Chalcedonians as a bishop than he did as a monk.

Sometime between 519 and 525 Severus of Antioch anwered a letter he received from Photius and Andrew on the subject of receiving clergy from Nestorian and Diphysite groups who renounce their heresy and make a right confession and on whether or not catechumens, the demon possed, and penitents should be present for the Lord's Supper. Severus of Antioch states that after a period of repentance they should be received into the same rank without re-baptism or re-ordination.
Severus sent a letter to non-Chalcedonian Christians in the city of Tyre about why Eutyches is anathematized even though he was received by Dioscorus.
When Severus became bishop of Antioch people led by Theodotus insisted that converts from the Nestorian heresy be re-anointed.
Gregory, although never himself ordained, performed ordinations. Severus held these to be illegal and required those ordained by him to be removed.
Severus advised that those who had been ordained by Theodotus, though he was a heretic, did not need to be re-ordained or re-annointed after making a proper profession of faith.
Severus recommended that Elisha sell the complete copy of that Bible that had been owned by John before his death, and use the funds for the care of the poor.

Severus wrote a letter to Valieriena thanking God for her new position as archimandritess and giving advice on how to lead the holy virgins under her care.

Severus advises Valeriena to encourage the virgins to an ascetic life, suggesting their isolation from men, sharing common meals, discouraging the owning of enslaved people, and emphasize physical labour.
Severus wrote a letter to Conon about the marriage of Conon's daughter. He merely recommended that she be given in marriage to someone of orthodox faith.
In his letter, Peter reported to Severus that Leontius had shaken the stability of the Church in Apamea.
Severus had become acquainted with Leontius through letters while living in Palestine.
Severus intended to ordain the scholastics Peter and Maximin.
Severus wrote a letter to John.
Severus wrote a letter to Solon arguing that the blessings of heaven are spiritual and not physical; eating, drinking, etc.

Severus responded to John by refusing to accept the synod of Chalcedon as a repudiation of Nestorius and Eutyches, because the Chalcedonian creed and the Tome of Leo support Nestorianism; Severus does not believe that anathematizing Eutyches makes the Council of Chalcedon legitimate, because the followers of Arius were still heretics even though they repudiated the teachings of Sabellius.
Severus encouraged Peter to ordain the scholastics John son of Matronian and Sergius.

Severus defended his ordination practices by pointing out that many other godly bishops approved, including Julian, who allowed Severus to ordain the deacon Irenaeus, and Dionysius, who allowed Severus to ordain the deacon Anatolius.
Contrary to the opinion of Peter, Severus had not ordained Leontius out of need, but in order to honour the man.
Between 513 to 518, Severus wrote a letter to Timostratus the Duke about the importance of ordination.
Severus wrote a letter to Cosmas on the subject of forgiving those who involuntarily commune with heretic provided they confess their sin.
Severus encouraged Constantine to follow his teaching and the advice of Peter the Presbyter and to be alert for John's blacksiding.

Severus was aware of many letters written by Peter to himself and to the presbyter Thomas, wherein Peter accused Severus and others of breaking canon-law and tradition by allowing for ordinations outside of the diocese.

Following the example of Constantine, Severus encouraged Solon to commune only with orthodox clergy, rather than following the example of Anastasius who had supported the Henotikon.

Severus argued that by ordaining priests in a diocese that was not his own, Epiphanius was not violating the sacred canons, which only outlaws such behavior in the cases of bishops forcing themselves on other dioceses, citing the examples of Eusebius of Samosata during the controversy of Arius, Theodoret, Basil, and Gregory the Theologian.

Sergius, who was the disciple of Simeon was also a monk and a recluse, who lived an aescetic life in an enclosure. In order to avoid idleness, Simeon and Sergius taught young boys and infants from their enclosure through a window.
After serving God for forty-seven years,Simeon died.
After twenty years, Sergius received permission from Simeon to leave the monastery and shut himself up in a certain place close to the village.

Sergius was confined on the third floor in the middle of the monastery of 'Tryz and tortured. After some time, Sergius managed to escape by slipping out of his irons and jumping from the third-floor window. Sergius returned to Simeon and received permission to build a monastery in the settlement of Qlwfyte.

Shortly after Sergius established the monastery of Qlwfyte, his adversaries came to pull it down. Sergius told his enemies that he would rebuild it each time it was destroyed, so they finally left him alone. Sergius rebuilt the monastery of Qlwfyte and invited Simeon to stay with him. Sergius died after Simeon's arrival.

Whenever a stranger came to Simeon's door, he would demonstrate great hospitality and feast with his guest as if he were Christ. However, when he was not in the presence of strangers seeking shelter, he fasted for up to ten days at a time and dedicated his efforts to praying all day and most of the night, rarely sleeping more than two hours a night.

Simeon was a recluse who lived in a walled monastery. He spent much of his time standing on a wall in order to fulfill two purposes: seclusion and the entertainment of strangers. He began living as a recluse in 483.

Simeon travelled as far as the camp of the Saracens of the Tribe of Nu'man and converted many to Christianity. He persuaded certain magnates who had converted to Christianity build Christian churches.
Babai, Catholicus of Seleucia, called a debate among the bishops in Persia, in which Simeon participated after they appointed the King's Marzban as the moderator.
Simeon died

Simeon travelled far and wide to preach against the followers of Theodore , Nestorius , Mani , Bar Daisan , and Marcion . He travelled from Jerusalem to Illyricum and Persia and Constantinople to spread the Christian faith.
Simeon met with Anastasius and asked him to urge Kawad to let the Christians in Persia live in peace. Anastasius convinced Kawad to leave the Persian Christians alone.
John of Ephesus commemorated Simeon.

Because Simeon humiliated so many heretical leaders whenever he debated with them, many wanted him dead. In order to move about in safety, Simeon wore his hair and beard long in the style of a Persian layman.
Simeon travelled through Persia and into Rome in order to convert more people to Christianity.
Simeon visited the Christians in Hirtha Nu'man
Simeon gained a reputation among the leaders and doctors of the heretical movements in various countries for being a great debater. He was nicknamed the Invincible Satan, Simeon the debater.

Simeon asked Theodora to send a letter to the Queen of the Persians concerning the safety of the Christian community in Persia. Theodora complied with his wish and kept the aged and very frail Simeon close to her until the end of his life.
Simeon was ordained Bishop of Beth Arsham

The Marzban declared Simeon the winner of the debate with Babai. Simeon's easy victory humiliated the Nestorians and prompted the Christian bishops to convince Simeon to be promoted to Bishop of Beth Arsham.
For seven years, Simeon travelled to different Christian communities in order to confirm their belief in the Christian faith.
After seven hard years in prison, Simeon was released.
Simeon travelled wherever heresy was taking root and debated with those who promoted heresy until they all fell silent.
Simeon also battled the Magian heresy and converted three distinguished Magians to Christianity.

The presbyter of Simeon stayed with the good Christian patrician Probus for two years, where he managed Simeon's extensive collection of sermons and letters. He remained there until the time of his death.

Anonymi 3662 who followed Susan into exile became very distressed over her absence because they did not know that she had taken up residence in the hermit's cave.
Susan found the cave in the desert near the village of Mendis and went into it without telling anyone. She went without food and water for several days.

Maro and Anonymi 3665 settled near Susan and Anonymi 3662. Many others followed and settled near the holy sisters. Anonymi 3662 and Susan did not wish to cause scandal by living in such close proximity to men, so they endeavored to leave their tower and go further into the desert.
After ten days, people of the village were moved by the sisters' weeping and distress and discovered that Susan had been living in the hermit's cave.
Susan, who was attacked by demons in the cave day and night, thought that anonymi 3695 who discovered her were fiends as well. She did not respond to them when they called out to her.
Anonymous 3668 asked Susan why she hasn't shown her face to a man in twenty-five years and she said that it would cause her and the person who beheld her face great suffering.

Anonymi 3695 went to fetch Anonymi 3662, who immediately came to the cave to retrieve Susan. Susan did not respond to their entreaties, since demons had visited her the day before disguised as the sisters in an attempt to dislodge her from the hermitage.
There was a cave outside the tower in the desert near Mendis, where Anonymous 3663 once dwelt and to which Susan travelled.

Maro and and his ten disciples had been Susan's neighbors in a monastery in Palestine before they were driven out of their monastery by the Chalcedonian persecution. They made their way to Susan and Anonymi 3662.

Maro and Anonymi 3665 felt ashamed once they learned of Susan's plan to remove herself and Anonymi 3662 to the desert and offered to build them an enclosed monastery with a tower within the village, so that they could be isolated but remain close to the other holy men and women who travelled to be near her. Susan reluctantly agreed.

God granted Susan power over the fiends that attacked her day and night in the form of human beings. She continued in this way for fifteen years as her fame grew and people came from far and wide to visit with her and hear her speak. She never showed her face when she spoke in public.

Even though Anonymi 3662 managed to convince Susan that they were not demons, she refused to return to the monastery with them as she wished to live as a hermit. They agreed to bring her a jug of water and seven bread cakes a week for her sustenance on the condition that she will not leave without giving them prior notice. This went on for three years, during which time the fame of the Susan and her sisters grew.

Anonymous 3668 who lived in the desert was regularly assailed by demons and was not as successful as Susan in fighting them. After seeking her advice, she told him that her power over demons comes from Christ and that he should not fear demons if he opposes them in the name of the all-powerful Lord. The man felt ashamed, but was strengthened against the demons.
Susan was strong as adamant against the demons and showed no fear of them. They complained bitterly about her strength.
Anonymi 3664 came to Susan and Anonymi 3352 from Alexandria and from Libya.
Susan chose to go into exile into the desert beyond Alexandria.
Susan changed her name so that she would remain hidden from her parents who were searching for her.
The majority of the nuns in Susan's convent conformed, but some chose exile.
Susan dedicated herself to fasting, praying, and keeping vigil, which after two years, made her the most devout person in the monastery.
Susan was at first refused admission to the monastery due to her age, but after three days of waiting outside the gate and weeping, she was admitted.
Susan's companions in the monastery were skeptical of her devotion and tested her.
After ten years of service in the monastery, the Chalcedonian persecution forced Susan and the nuns to choose between conforming or going into exile.
Of the women who had submitted to the judgments of the Council of Chalcedon, five nuns rejected it and followed Susan into exile.
A tower was erected in Mar Menas for protection, in which the women who followedSusan dwelt and made a living from the labor of their hands.
Susan heard of a place beyond the House of Mars Menas and directed her steps there.
Susan put her soul into the Lord's hands and fled from her parents.
After three or four miles, Susan came upon a large party of women and men travelling to Jerusalem and joined them.
After worshipping in Jerusalem, the men and women in Susan's party tried unsuccessfully to bring Susan back with them.
Susan sought out the women's monastery between Ascalon and Gaza.
At the age of eight, Susan wanted to go on pilgrimage, but Susan's parents denied her permission.

In 542/43 This regularized date was calculated by the SPEAR editor from a non-calendrical dating system such as regnal years, etc. During the sixteenth year of the reign of Justinian , at the request of Hereth Bar Gabala, Theodora ordered the ordination of non-Chalcedonian bishops: Jacob Baradaeus as bishop of Edessa and Theodore of Hirtha as bishop of Hirtha of the Saracens.
John exercised judgment when deciding who he would ordain. The jealous bishops, meanwhile, plotted to reveal John's actions to the queen.

Theodosius and the rest of the bishops were sent into exile. Along with three hundred clergy and saint Zura, they travelled to a fortress called Dereus in Thrace. They were supported in the court by Empress Theodora.

Following the self-exile of Anthimus, Theodora hid him in one of her palaces. Only she and Anonymous 3768 and Anonymous 3769 knew about this. He remained in hiding for ten years, ending with the death of Theodora.

Followers of the Council of Chalcedon expelled Christians from Alexandria and Mare from his desert cell. On account of the persecution,Mare resolved to travel to Constantinople to err his grievacnes with the king and queen.
Mare confronted Justinian and Theodora concerning the persecution. Because of his words and dress, they esteemed him a holy man, and gave him a hundred weight of gold, which he promptly threw away.

When Marefinished constructing the martyr's chapel and he knew his death was close, he knelt in his coffin to pray for three days and gave up his spirit. The king and queen sent chamberlains, senators, bishops, clergyman, and monks to bury Mare.
Abba continued to be persecuted and fled to the court of Empress Theodora.
Mare petitioned Justinian and Theodora for building materials and laborers so that he could build a martyr's chapel.
Feeling guilty about the hundredweight gold,the queen sent her chamberlains several times to Mare to seek his forgiveness.

Observing the holiness of Mare, Satan encouraged robbers to abuse him, under the impression that the queen's chamberlains were bringing him gold. Mare overtook his assailants by stealing their weapons and attacking them.
Theodora built a hospital on Chios.
After many years, Mare was fatigued due to his strenuous way of life. He sought out one of Theodora's chamberlains, who secured the goal necessary to buy a villa suited for a life of retreat.
Stephen and the sisters of Mare, Anonymous 3606 and Anonymous 3607, received permission from Theodora to take Mare's bones to his own country.

Thomas gave his keys to The bishop's cellarer and snuck out of his monastery at night to go to the pit, where he lived an ascetic life of prayer and fasting.

Thomas went to the Monastery of John Urtaya, where his sister Cosmo found him and pleaded with him to come home. He refused and remained at the monastery.

Mare and his men found an old man who sold utensils for a living in the village of Mendis. He lived in a community of other religious exiles. Stephen and Thomas asked the man to lead them to the exiles.
Thomas, Stephen, and Zwtʾ departed from the Convent of John Urtaya after two years and headed toward Egypt.

Zeʿora performed many acts of charity for the poor.
Zeʿora died, leaving behind his disciple Hananya.
Anonymous 3637 had ecclesiastical authority over Zeʿora.
Zeʿora took ten disciples and traveled to Constantinople in order to protest the treatment of the non-Chalcedonians to the emperor
Zeʿora and Anonymous 3635 were monks at the same monastery.
Justinian fell ill and Theodora hid him while she convinced Zeʿora to heal the emperor.
Habib died, leaving the monastery to Z'ura.
The emperor opposed Zeʿora who spoke boldly in defense of his non-Chalcedonian convictions and against the persecution of non-Chalcedonians. The emperor oppossed Zeʿora but also feared him.
Zeʿora made a column for himself and stood on it.

Agapetus sent a message to Zeʿora at a villa near Sycae, demanding he obey Justinian. Zeʿora refused. Anonymous 3645 tried to bring him back to the city but heavy winds prevented him crossing the Golden Horn.
John of Ephesus commemorated Zeʿora.
Habib sent his disciple Z'ura to pray over the demon-possessed man, who then died, his injustices being undone.
Zeʿora and Anonymi 3642 were fellow clergy.
Zeʿora studied under Anonymous 3634.

Zeʿora was a follower of Habib.
Zeʿora engaged in affective prayer.
Hananya studied under Zeʿora.
Zeʿora left the city for a camp in Thrace called Dercus where he dwelt together with Theodosius, Patriarch of Alexandria .
Zeʿora anathematized the Council of Chalcedon and inflicted the emperor with swelling and a compromised mental state.
The persecutors of Zeʿora sent letters to Constantinople to explain their treatment of Zeʿora.
The master of Zeʿora died.
The Huns arrived and threatened Zeʿora, probably in 515.
Chalcedonian persecutors removed Zeʿora from his column.
Zeʿora miraculously stopped a Hun from killing him, probably in 515.
From atop his column Zeʿora healed the sick by blessing water and sprinkling it on them.
Zeʿora miraculously restored a spring that had stopped flowing
Zeʿora's fame grew, extending as far as the city of Rome and enabling him to have great influence among the emperor and the senators. He used this influence to care for the poor.
Zeʿora restored Justinian to health and the emperor relented from pusuing strict persecution of non-Chalcedonians.
Pope Agapetus, who was about to blaspheme by declaring that Mary should not be commemorated in the church, urged the emperor to expel Zeʿora.
Agapetus died suddenly on the day predicted by Zeʿora and Anonymi 3646 accused him of using magic against the Pope.

Theodosius and the rest of the bishops were sent into exile. Along with three hundred clergy and saint Zura, they travelled to a fortress called Dereus in Thrace. They were supported in the court by Empress Theodora.

Zwtʾ died after Thomas.

Stephen saw that Thomas was residing in Monastery of John Urtaya and decided to join him, as did another monk who served under Mare, named Zota. All three men dwelled in the Monastery of John Urtaya for two years.

Stephen accepted the invitation and tried to convince Thomas and Zwtʾ to accompany him, but they refused and parted ways. Thomas wished to dedicated the remainder of his life to fasting and praying alone in the desert.

John of Ephesus found Thomas and Zota years later in the desert of Mendis by Mar Menas. Thomas's body was frail and sunburnt. He had dedicated his life to fasting, praying, so that by depriving the body he would purify the soul.
Thomas, Stephen, and Zwtʾ departed from the Convent of John Urtaya after two years and headed toward Egypt.
Mara, metropolitan of Amid had ecclesiastical authority over Zota.
John of Ephesus commemorated Zota.
Zwtʾ was the child of Abraham the Priest.
